thread.section_title: Latest business and finance news from New Zealand and the world's key markets - Yahoo New Zealand Finance
thread.title: $A lower despite post-RBA bounce

title: $A lower despite post-RBA bounce
text:
Print 
The Australian dollar has regained some ground after the Reserve Bank kept the cash rate unchanged and appears in no rush to cut in the coming months. 
At 1700 AEST on Tuesday, the local unit was trading at 74.85 US cents, down from 75.11 cents on Monday. 
During the day it fell as low as 74.63 US cents, close to a six year low, but bounced as high as 75.02 cents after the RBA's decision. 
In a statement explaining its decision, the RBA appeared more upbeat about the economy, saying the unemployment rate is steadying and borrowing rates are rising. 
It also appeared unconcerned about market turmoil in China and the Greek financial crisis, but still says the Australian dollar needs to fall further. 
"The RBA's policy meeting was largely a non-event for the Australian dollar," Forex.com research analyst Chris Tedder said. 
"However, the currency remains under pressure due to an ongoing massacre in Chinese equity markets, which is partly responsible for 5.4 per cent fall in the spot price of iron ore overnight." 
Mr Tedder said there is a chance the Australian dollar could establish itself back above 75 US cents. 
At 1700 AEST, the local currency was at 91.83 Japanese yen, down from Monday's close of 92.12 yen, and at 67.86 euro cents, down from 67.97 euro cents. 
The bond market is firmer despite future prices suffering a fall after the Reserve Bank decision. 
Nomura rate strategist Andrew Ticehurst said bond futures prices fell in response to the belief the RBA will keep the cash rate unchanged for the foreseeable future. 
"A very similar statement, no strong easing bias, they've retained the right for future action, if and when they see fit," he said. 
Although most in the market do not expect more cash rate cuts, Mr Ticehurst said Nomura expects a rate cut in November because of sub-trend economic growth. 
Before the RBA's rates call, bond futures price has risen, which Mr Ticehurst said could be due to overseas analysts being more downbeat about the Australian economy than local market players. 
At 1630 AEST on Tuesday, the September 2015 10-year bond futures contract was trading at 97.050 (implying a yield of 2.950 per cent), up from 97.020 (2.980 per cent) on Monday. 
The September 2015 three-year bond futures contract was at 98.050 (1.950 per cent), up from 98.030 (1.970 per cent). @YahooNZBusiness on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook China the worry, not Greece: S&P AAP
